title: Meghan Markle royal tour fiji market prince harry news security
story: The Duchess of Sussex visited Suva market which supports the UN Women's project 'Markets for Change&rsquo, but huge crowds sparked &ldquoabsolute chaos and the former Suits actress was rushed away after just six minutes.A worried Meghan Markle was seen whispering in to her aides ear just minutes before she was whisked away.&nbspThe vendors were left devastated as they had been waiting for hours to meet Meghan.READ MORE: MEGHAN MARKLE AND PRINCE HARRY ROYAL TOUR LIVE                Prince Harry downs drink BANNED in Europe because it can cause DEATHOfficials said they cut short the scheduled visit over the security risk with a royal aide saying it was hot, humid and uncomfortably busy.Kensington Palace suggested the decision to leave early was taken due to crowd management issues.A royal source said: The visit was cut slightly short due to the large number of people within the market, which made the event uncomfortably busy. There were much bigger crowds than people had been anticipating and there were a lot of people cramped into the market.A royal aide said the market visit was an extension of an earlier engagement where the duchess heard about the Markets for Change project at a morning tea.The aide added: She met everyone she was meant to meet and left.Meghan Markle&rsquos visit to Fiji&rsquos street market was cut short due to a &ldquosecurity risk (Image: PA )On advice she was taken out due to crowd management issues.Royal sources said there was a security issue because of the much bigger crowds than anticipated inside the market, making the event uncomfortably busy.Dramatic video footage shows the moment her aides and chief bodyguard quickly escorted her through the crowds.Visibly shaken, Meghan put her hand to her head as she made her way through the crowds.Meghan Markle was whisked away just moments after she had whispered in her aides ear  (Image: PA )Meghan Markle looked flustered in the busy crowds  (Image: AFP)Asenaca Salusalu, the first vendor to meet the duchess inside the market, told how Meghan was afraid.&nbspMrs Salusalu, 50, a farmer from the village of Nukulau, more than 100 kilometres from Suva, has been a stallholder at the market for nine years, selling root crops, vegetables and fruits.Meghan, who looked slightly flustered during the hurried walk through the market, shook Mrs Salusalu's hand, and said: It's very good to meet you, before moving on.Mrs Salusalu said: She didn't really speak at all, like she was a bit afraid. She just said 'Bula' and 'Nice to meet you'. But I'm happy to have met her.Meghan Markle's security aides whisked her through the crowds  (Image: AFP )Stallholders told of their disappointment at not being able to meet Prince Harry's pregnant wife.&nbspOne said: It's such a shame as we were all very excited to meet her.&nbspWe started preparing for the visit three weeks ago and had been meant to meet her but she left without even saying hello.Market vendor Nina Tuimouta Koro said the women had been practising songs to sing to the Duchess as they waited for the Royal to arrive.&nbspThe vendors were left devastated as they had been waiting for hours to meet Meghan (Image: Reuters)Earlier in the day, Ms Tuimouta Koro said: &ldquoAt the moment, we are practising two songs which we will sing for her Royal Highness, which is &lsquoMe da laveta&rsquo and the farewell song - Isa isa vulgar last dina.&ldquoAfter that, we will gift them a bouquet of flowers.It is not clear whether the women got to sing their songs and deliver their gifts to the Duchess.A source from Kensington Palace said the Duchess was removed from the area due to &ldquomassive crowds which had formed around the market.Mirror photographer Ian Vogler, who was at the scene, said: &ldquoIt was crowded inside the market and really cramped.Mr Vogler added: The alleyways in the market were very narrow and I could understand why Meghan's personal protection officers would judge it to be an unsafe environment, especially with her being pregnant.It was also very hot and humid in the market and there were a lot of people in very close quarters to the Duchess, which explains why she was rushed away.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are currently on their landmark 16-day trip to Oceania - the first major tour the Royal duo have undertaken since they tied the knot in May.Even though Meghan has cut down her schedule due to her pregnancy, which was announced as she left for Australia last week, the former Suits actress was expected to attend all her engagements in Fiji today. A source from Kensington Palace said the Duchess was removed from the area due to &ldquomassive crowds (Image: Reuters)After her short visit to Suva market, Meghan is due to visit the British High Commission (Image: Getty)This morning, the Royal duo visited the University of the South Pacific campus where they observed a cultural performance on the effects of climate change and delivered speeches.After her short visit to Suva market, Meghan is due to visit the British High Commission.The Duke is attending a separate ceremony at the Coo-I-Suva forest site to unveil Fiji's contribution to the Queen's Commonwealth Canopy Project.Additional reporting by Martina Bet&nbsp

title: Megham Markle Prince Harry news royal tour Fiji South Pacific university speech
story: The Duchess of Sussex used the speech to speak about the importance of access to education for all during her first official speech during the royal tour of Fiji, and only her second ever as a member of the royal family.Meghan spoke movingly of the &ldquofeeling of pride and excitement that comes with attending university but revealed that she struggled with the cost of tuition as she addressed an audience at the University of the South Pacific today.The Duchess said it was through &ldquoscholarships, financial aid programmes and earnings from a job on campus she was able to afford to attend university.&nbsp&ldquoWithout question, it was worth every effort, she added.                REVEALED: Why Meghan Markle DID NOT wear tiara at Fiji state dinner                Prince Harry samples &lsquoHALLUCINOGENIC&rsquo drink on second day of tourAfter addressing the audience with a traditional greeting, she spoke of her pleasure to be on the island, before delivering the moving address on education.In her passionate speech she said: &ldquoAs a university graduate, I know the personal feeling of pride and excitement that comes with attending university, from the moment you receive the acceptance letter to exams you spend countless late nights studying for.&ldquoI am also fully aware of the challenges of being able to afford this level of schooling for many people around the world, myself included.It was with scholarships, financial aid programmes and earnings from a job on campus that went directly towards my tuition that I was able to attend university and without question, it was worth every effort.Meghan Markle delivered an emotional address to University of the South Pacific  (Image: Getty)&ldquoEveryone should be afforded the opportunity to receive the education that they want, but more importantly the education that they have the right to receive.&ldquoAnd for women and girls in developing countries, this is vital.The Duchess of Sussex also announced two new grants for the Fiji National University and the University of the South Pacific.Meghan added: &ldquoSo I am very pleased to announce today that two new grants will be awarded to Fiji National University and the University of the South Pacific, allowing each of them to run workshops, which empower their female staff.&ldquoThis means that female faculty members are able to encourage others to follow in their footsteps and enter higher education and that more women become part of the decision making process in academic institutions.Prince Harry also delivered a speech to students, during which he launched four new Queen Elizabeth scholarships.Before taking the stage, the Royal duo enjoyed a colourful performance on climate change by singers and dancers at the university, after being presented with traditional Fijian leis adorned with flowers.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are currently on their major 16-day trip to Oceania - the first one the Royal duo has done together since they tied the knot last May.Even though Meghan has cut down her schedule due to her pregnancy, which was announced as she left for Australia last week, the former Suits actress will attend all her engagements in Fiji today.But before she addressed the students at the University of the South Pacific today, she was rushed out of a market where she was attending an official engagement, as large crowds sparked security fears.

story: Speaking to Adam Boulton on Sky News&rsquos All Out Politics, Mr Bridgen said that leaving the European Union would become &ldquoirresistible to the Republic of Ireland once they became a major contributor to the European Union&rsquos coffers after the UK has left the bloc.&nbspThe MP for North West Leicestershire also pointed to the appeal of free trade deals with the United States as a reason the Republic of Ireland may leave, as well as issues surrounding corporation tax and the military.The Brexiteer told Mr Boulton this afternoon: &ldquoWhat the European Union are desperately seeking to avoid is the good people of the Republic of Ireland, who are still in the EU, looking across the virtual border into Northern Ireland.A land of milk and honey, where we&rsquove got tree trade deals with countries around the world, including the USA, which is the Republic of Ireland&rsquos largest trading partner, that they can&rsquot join into.                UK faces &lsquoCRIMINAL GANGS&rsquo as border isn&rsquot ready for no-dea Brexit&ldquoBecause what they know is the Republic of Ireland will be leaving the European Union very very quickly.&ldquoEven faster is the EU try to enforce a hard border.Mr Bridgen continued: &ldquoIf we get out of the European Union, we can do free trade deals, if we do free trade deals it will be irresistible for lots of reasons.&ldquoThe Republic of Ireland will become a net contributor for the first time when we leave, they&rsquove got major problems with their corporation tax which has been very useful to their economy is far lower than the EU wants.Brexit news: The Brexiteer MP Andrew Bridgen has claimed the Republic of Ireland will leave EU  (Image: Sky News)They want harmonisation so they&rsquoll be forced to raise their corporation taxes, and also this European army project.&ldquoThe Republic of Ireland is a neutral country. They&rsquoll have to have a referendum to change their constitution to supply troops to a European army, that&rsquos going to cause them a major headache.Brexit negotiations have reached a major impasse over the Northern Irish border.Prime Minister Theresa May told MPs that while a deal was on its way, the Irish border was still a &ldquoconsiderable sticking point.At last week&rsquos EU council summit, European leaders scrapped plans for a special one-off&nbspBrexitsummit in November, saying &ldquonot enough progress had been made.Mrs May defended her offer of an&nbspextended transition period&nbspsaying this was &ldquoundesirable and would have to end &ldquowell before May 2022.But a solution on how to prevent a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic remains elusive, and&nbsptime is running out&nbsp- the UK is due to leave the EU on March 29, 2019.

story: Sadiq Khan jokingly bragged that he beat Mo Farah in a race while discussing his participation in the &lsquoDaily Mile&rsquo school run initiative earlier this week.Speaking on LBC, the Mayor for London quipped: &ldquoLast week I was out a school in east London running the Daily Mile with a chap called Mo Farah, before chuckling: &ldquoI beat him by the way, but we were both beaten by 10-year-olds.He added: &ldquoWhat we&rsquore encouraging all schools across London to do is to run the daily mile.&ldquoIt&rsquos just 15 minutes throughout the course of the day where children will initially warm up and walk, then run for 15 minutes and it&rsquos about a mile.                Remainer celebrities who funded buses for the London march REVEALED                We were DECEIVED on Brexit! Khan savages EU exit vote in French paper&ldquoThe evidence from Scotland where this began, but also elsewhere where they do this, can lead to fewer children being obese or overweight.The Mayor of London&rsquos comments were in response to a caller questioning the effectiveness of his takeaway policy in schools.Laura from Stevenage said: &ldquoI spoke to you earlier this year about your takeaway policy around schools in your London plan, and I said it wasn&rsquot going to work.&ldquoToday or yesterday there&rsquos been some figures released saying that there&rsquos been an increase in the number of takeaways across the country and in particularly some areas of London.Sadiq Khan: the Mayor of London joked he beat the Olympic gold medallist in a race (Image: LBCGetty)&ldquoSo my question is, with the release of these figures, whether you&rsquore going to look at your intervention, maybe change something or make some additions.&ldquoBecause I did mention to you some things you could be doing more in schools, in addition to what you&rsquore already doing.Worrying figures show that a record number of 10 and 11-year-olds are severely obese, with obesity rates in the most deprives areas of England more than double that in the least deprived.The National Child Measurement Programme, overseen by Public Health England, found that 4.2 per cent of 10 and 11-year-olds in England were severely obese last year.It represents a rise of more than a third from 200607, when records began. One in five children was either obese or severely obese as they prepared to leave primary school.Poorest Tam Fry, of the National Obesity Forum, said: The figures show a continuing increase of obesity. Of more concern the NHS is listing the number of 'severely obese' for the first time.Successive governments have been told since 2004 that children's body mass should be assessed yearly throughout their school years, but have pointedly ignored the advice.The tragic consequence is these children will not be assessed again at school and, without help, will probably end up as very obese adults.

title: defenders plea pm hounded military veterans
story: Troops in Northern Ireland in 1971 (Image: PopperfotoGetty Images)The letter, organised by former defence minister Mark Francois, was signed by four former chiefs of the defence staff - the uniformed heads of the Services - as well as a former First Sea Lord and a former head of the Army.Other signatories included former defence secretaries Lord King and Sir Michael Fallon and Tory MPs who have served in the Forces such as Richard Benyon, Colonel Bob Stewart and Johnny Mercer.Labour MPs backing the letter included Kate Hoey and Ruth Smeeth.The two-page letter tells Mrs May to honour her 2017 election pledge to protect our brave Armed Forces personnel from persistent legal claims which distress those who risk their lives for us, cost the taxpayer millions and undermine the Armed Forces.                Ulster veteran refuses life-saving treatment to clear name                Veteran hounded by nation he served is a disgrace &ndash STEPHEN POLLARDFour British veterans - three of them elderly - face trial over Northern Ireland shootings dating back to 1972 as part of investigations into so-called legacy killings.All were cleared of wrongdoing at the time.They include Dennis Hutchings, 77, who is seriously ill.The  this week revealed that the pressure has driven him to suicidal thoughts.Another 278 cases involving British soldiers in Northern Ireland also face re-investigation.Yet under Tony Blair's 1998 Good Friday Agreement, 500 terrorists were freed from prison early and about 300 suspects were given letters of comfort or on the run letters guaranteeing they would not be prosecuted.The Northern Ireland witch-hunt follows the persecution over several years of thousands of Iraq war veterans.Dennis Hutchings with MP Richard Benyon (Image: Tim Clarke)More than 3,500 claims were levelled at them, mostly by a now disgraced firm of solicitors.This led to taxpayer costs of &pound60million without leading to one prosecution.There are fears that veterans of future and past conflicts such as the Falklands will be sucked into the legal maelstrom without firm action by Downing Street.The letter states: It is blatantly obvious that the current process of investigating and re-investigating veterans, for incidents which were all investigated at the time, is completely at odds with the Government's manifesto commitments and the Armed Forces Covenant. We therefore believe that this situation simply cannot be allowed to continue as it is.It adds: The Iraq Historic Allegations Team furore showed us how our judicial system can be abused and how it can damage our security services.The legacy of the Northern Ireland Troubles threatens to do just the same, and we believe it is time for the Government to act comprehensively and put it all behind us.                Army veteran completes THIS challenge for The Royal British Legion                May under pressure to END expats state pension FREEZEBeginning of letter to Theresa May (Image: NC)We call upon you as Prime Minister to work alongside the Secretary of State for Defence, the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland and the Attorney General to ensure we find a solution to this challenging and complex problem.The letter insists that any solution must cover veterans of Northern Ireland, Iraq and Afghanistan together.The Northern Ireland Office recently closed a consultation on proposals to create a Historic Inquiries Unit to tackle 'legacy' killings.The plan was slammed earlier this year by Justice for Northern Ireland Veterans as paving the way to breaches of human rights laws.Signatories of yesterday's letter said the present plans as set out in the Stormont House Agreement clearly put our service and security personnel at an exceptional disadvantage.Mrs May's official spokesman said 16,000 people had responded to the NIO consultation but he did not comment on the public letter.He said: You will know that there is a consultation which has been taking place in relation to this issue. The consultation was to allow everyone a say on the proposals in the 2014 Stormont House Agreement in relation to 'legacy' and how we best move forward. Everyone deserves the opportunity to be heard.Second part of the letter to Theresa May with signatures (Image: NC)The Government will consider carefully all views received and provide a response as soon as we can. Overall, 16,000 people have responded to the consultation.The chief executive of Belfast-based Relatives for Justice, Mark Thompson, whose brother was killed by the Army in 1990, dismissed claims that troops were independently investigated during The Troubles.He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that the system was constructed in such a way to prevent justice being done.Mr Thompson said: When it comes to the British Army and the Tory Party and rule of law, they want to talk about the rule of law when it is applied to everyone else but not the soldiers.More than 3,500 people were killed including 722 members of the Armed Forces and Police during The Troubles between the late 1960s and 1998.Government figures suggest that 60 per cent of killings were caused by Republican terrorists, mainly factions of the IRA, 30 per cent by Loyalist paramilitaries, and 10 per cent by members of state forces who in almost all cases were acting within the law.From top to bottom: Julian Lewis MP, Admiral Lord West, Colonel Bob Stewart (Image: )Pledge of support from the Defence SecretaryDEFENCE Secretary Gavin Williamson yesterday vowed to support accused elderly veterans.Prime Minister Theresa May has also already told Attorney General Geoffrey Cox to find a solution.A team has been set up in the Cabinet Office, taking advice from the Ministry of Defence and the Northern Ireland Office.They will have to take into account the findings of the NIO's consultation on the legacy killings which drew 16,000 responses from the public.Recommendations are due to be sent by Christmas with an announcement in the new year. Mr Williamson is known to favour a time limit for prosecutions.He told the : We are indebted to those who served with great courage and distinction to bring about peace and security in Northern Ireland.That is why I don't want to see elderly veterans having to face repeated investigations decades after the events in question.He said the MoD has put in place a comprehensive package of support, including legal representation to any inidual accused of an offence arising from their service on operations.From top to bottom: Richard Dannatt, Richard Benyon MP, Mark Francois MP (Image: )COMMENT BY JOHN INGHAMBREXIT is far from the only political minefield Theresa May has to navigate, the Prime Minister was reminded yesterday.Providing closure over killings in Northern Ireland's Troubles is just as tough.The general election left her dependent on the Democratic Unionist Party and firmly dumped veterans in the crossfire between Sinn Fein and the unionists.She must find a solution that is legally sound but satisfies the unionists by not letting the IRA off the hook.The shameful betrayal of veterans, dispatched to Northern Ireland to keep the peace and now being hounded in their later years, has infuriated Mrs May's backbenchers.Fears persist that the Northern Ireland legal system continues to be riven with sectarianism, with avowed republicans among the judiciary.Small wonder British soldiers facing trial in the province have no confidence they will get a fair hearing.One effective option would be to give the UK Attorney General the final say on whether veterans can be prosecuted. Another is to ensure cases investigated at the time cannot be reinvestigated without significant new evidence.Terror suspects given comfort letters by Tony Blair - and who have not been fully investigated - could go to trial. This though would be fiercely resisted by Sinn Fein.An alternative is a South Africa-style Truth and Reconciliation Commission where perpetrators could detail their actions without incriminating themselves.This would give closure but stick in the craw of many.The nuclear option is for the UK to quit the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) and leave its troops governed instead by the Geneva Convention.The ECHR allows lethal force only as a last resort, in contrast to the Geneva Convention, which allows it as a first resort against an enemy.Unlike the UK, the US is not governed by the ECHR. Unlike British veterans, their US counterparts do not live in fear of a knock on the door, years after returning from battle.

title: EU news Italy budget Guy Verhofstadt European Commission latest
story: The influential Belgian MEP accused EU leaders of &ldquoevading their responsibility after they left the European Council summit negotiating table without finalising promised Eurozone reform.The warning comes after Italy was hit by unprecedented action from the European Commission as top officials fear the country&rsquos rogue populist budget could act as a contagion to another financial crash.Mr Verhofstadt told MEPs in Strasbourg the EU must shoulder the responsibility for allowing such &ldquofree riding behaviour from the populist Five Star Movement and League coalition in Rome.&ldquoIt has now been ten years since the outbreak of the financial crisis and no new governance systems for the Eurozone have been put in place, he said.EU news: Guy Verhofstadt warns leaders to resolve Italy budget or face financial crash (Image: EbS)&ldquoWake up Mr Tusk, the next financial crisis is knocking on our door.He added: &ldquoMr Tusk, the way you and your colleagues in the Council evade their responsibility is a dereliction of duty sleep walking to a new financial catastrophe.&ldquoWhen are you going to change your methods?&ldquoWhen are you going to lock your colleagues into a meeting room &ndash no new clothes, no new underwear &ndash until they have taken their responsibility, until they have reformed our migration policies?                Pound euro exchange rate: GBP trading in narrow range on Brexit                Pound US dollar exchange rate: GBP drops as mortgage approvals fallOn Tuesday, European Commission officials gave Rome three weeks to resubmit its draft budget after the bloc took issue with plans to run at a 2.4 percent of GDP deficit in 2019.If Rome defies its orders from Brussels, officials could begin an &ldquoexcessive deficit procedure, leading to sanctions of 0.5 percent of annual GDP or &euro9billion.Italy&rsquos proposed 2.4 percent budget deficit is under the EU limit set by Brussels but officials argue the country&rsquos growing public debt, at 131 percent of GDP, has given them cause to crackdown.Valdis Dombrovskis, the European commissioner responsible for the euro, said the the European Commission had &ldquono alternative but demand Rome rip up its budget.He said: &ldquoThe euro area is built on strong bonds of trust, underpinned by rules that are the same for everybody. It is our job and duty to uphold common interest and mutual commitments taken by the member countries.Italy's debt is among the highest in Europe, and Italian taxpayers spend about the same amount on it as on education.In this spirit, we see no alternative but to request the Italian government to revise its draft budgetary plan for 2019, and we look forward to an open and constructive dialogue in the weeks to come.Luigi Di Maio, the head of the Five Star Movement, said Italy would not change its mind on the deficit.He said: &ldquoWe won&rsquot stop, we know we are on the right path.

title: right to ignore peoples vote
story: We have had a “people’s vote”. It was in June  and .million people voted to leave the EU. That puts the few hundred thousand on yesterday’s march in perspective, doesn’t it Just because those voters didn’t get dressed up for an afternoon stroll doesn’t make their democratic input any less signicant. The Remain propaganda leaflet sent to every household before the Referendum — at the cost of millions of pounds to the taxpayer — laid out what that vote meant: “The Government will implement what you decide.”It’s beyond us why anybody would want to jump back into bed with the EU. They’ve exposed themselves as devious ideologues whose only interest is sticking the boot into Britain for wanting to go it alone, like a bitter ex who refuses to hand back a sweatshirt.This week, the US confirmed they’ll start trade talks as soon as we leave. The rest of the world will soon follow.It’s time to look forward, not back. This country has an exciting future ahead.ANJEM Choudary shouldn’t be free to stalk Britain’s streets.Our revelation today that he will “never” stop spewing his hateful creed shows that this vicious leopard won’t change his spots. That he will now challenge legitimate restrictions on his activities because they breach his “human rights” beggars belief.Ask the parents of children killed in Manchester about “human rights”.  Ask those caught up in the Westminster and London Bridge attacks whether Choudary should be free to inspire extremists to commit horric atrocities.He and those like him should be inside — and we should throw away the key.THE charge sheet against John Bercow gets longer by the day.It’s hardly a surprise he’s blocking proper action on bullying in Westminster. The pint-sized Speaker appears to be the worst of the lot.We’re used to his attention-grabbing stunts in the Chamber. But his behaviour behind the scenes is far more concerning.He has promised to quit next summer. That’s not good enough. The longer he is in the Speaker’s chair, the more shame he brings on Parliament.Go now, man.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: make this budget philips last
story: Next Monday, on the eve of Halloween, Phil Hammond will raise the curtain on his latest tax-hiking non-Tory Budget.If there’s any justice, it will be his last.If Theresa May’s Downing Street days are numbered, so should those be of her Death Watch Chancellor.Together, they are the unrivalled stars of Tory MP Johnny Mercer’s glorious Whitehall farce, “The Sh*t Show”.Excitable critics say Mrs May is entering a “killing zone”.Rivals jockey for position while party chiefs try to streamline the timetable for picking her successor.This Prime Minister’s Number Ten tenancy is almost up. So is Hammond’s next door.Whoever takes over — Boris, David Davis or Jeremy Hunt — needs an emergency clear-out.The big guns of the Treasury need to be pointed at the “enemy” not its own side.After two long, wasted years, Britain is engaged in an unexpectedly desperate fight, not just to salvage Brexit but to save British democracy.Weekend crowds demanding a second referendum seem oblivious to the threat such a crazy re-run would pose to this nation’s centuries-old stability, ironically the envy of Europe.We cannot reverse the  referendum without turning Brexit into a perpetual running sore. And Britain can never rejoin the EU except on its knees.The only way to put this corrosive issue to bed is for Brexit to succeed — as it will, despite treacherous Tony Blair and Facebook hypocrite Nick Clegg.To succeed as we must we need a new chancellor as well as a new prime minister.Diehard Remainer Phil Hammond should be first out the door.It was Spreadsheet Phil who vetoed vital preparations for No Deal — now a better-than - prospect with time rapidly running out.And it was Hammond who surrendered the one negotiating weapon Brussels fears most — a thriving, low-tax Britain competing with the EU on its doorstep.Our economic fate is entirely in our hands. We can make taxes and tarfs as competitive as we like.Better investment incentives and lower corporation tax rates would trigger a flood of foreign investment in UK plc — and ensure car makers like Nissan and Toyota never leave our shores.Yet the British Chancellor of the Exchequer has ruled them out.“Phil is like those Harry Potter Dementor creatures,” says a top Tory. “He sucks the le out of any room he happens to be in.”Hammond is easily replaced. Michael Gove, an ex-future PM but a formidable Cabinet minister, has the drive and imagination to take on the Treasury “Blob”.There is no shortage of Brexit talent on the Tory benches.Just compare thundering Attorney General Geoffrey Cox QC with prissy dried-stick predecessor Dominic Grieve.Grieve is busy sabotaging Brexit. Cox finds ways to make it work.He is now “marking Number Ten’s homework” on Mrs May’s wretched Northern Ireland “backstop”.Some even tip him as a dark horse in the leadership stakes.There is one other big change needed at the heart of Britain’s Brexit team.Our next PM must have a new EU negotiator.Nobody could be worse than Olly Robbins, already reportedly eyeing up a £m-a-year golden parachute into a top City job.Lelong Europhile Robbins has led Mrs May into so many disastrous EU traps — especially her humiliation in Salzburg — he is often cast as an EU “double agent”.It was Robbins who told EU negotiator Michel Barnier that Britain might stay indefinitely in “transition” while the fantasy Northern Ireland backstop was sorted out.And pay £bn more on top of the £bn ransom for the privilege.The idea that Robbins is the “EU’s man in Whitehall” is not such a stretch when you consider his Jeremy Corbyn-style applause for Communist Russia.Kremlin leaders, he told fellow Oxford students in , “changed Russia from a backward peasant autocracy, despised by the West, into a technological giant at whom the world cowered in fear for half a century.”Everyone is entitled to youthful naivety.But can anyone imagine Olly Robbins fighting our corner for EU democracy and accountability, let alone the referendum verdict of .m Brexit-voting Brits SAUDI Arabia’s rulers must be really annoyed with dissident Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.This elderly trouble maker walked alone into his country’s Turkish consulate knowing he might never emerge alive.He was clearly looking for trouble.Once inside, using his bare hands, he attacked a gang of  innocent Saudi torturers who had just flown in for a couple of hours’ holiday armed only with a bone saw and a hypodermic syringe.Then, to the embarrassment of kindly Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, he went and hid his own body.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brexit finish line in sight
story: Has it been a good day or a bad day for me  Am I up or down “How are YOU doing Prime Minister ” one journalist asked me recently. I didn’t reply at the time but I’m going to give Sun readers the answer now – and it’s very simple.None of this is about me. It’s all about you.That’s why, when I’m confronted with tough choices during the Brexit negotiations, I don’t think about what the implications are for me. Instead, I ask myself what it means for you, for your family and for the whole of the United Kingdom.Am I bringing back control of your money, your borders and your laws Am I protecting your jobs and making sure nothing gets in the way of our brilliant entrepreneurs and small businesses Am I protecting the integrity of the United Kingdom And, above all, am I delivering the Brexit that the people of this country so clearly voted for I need to be able to answer “Yes” to every one of these questions.Andthat means there are some dficult days in Brussels, well that’s just something I have to deal with.Because the Brexit talks are not about me or my personal fortunes. They’re about the national interest – and that means making the right choices, not the easy ones.Inevitably, that will take time. Brexit is the UK’s biggest constitutional change for generations. Unpicking more than  years of treaties, agreements and laws would be a challenge under any circumstances and, as no country has ever left the EU before, it’s not asthere’s an instruction manual for those either side of the negotiating table to follow.I know it can seem like the talks are never-ending, and that many of you have been frustrated by the endless back and forth on technical points – I certainly feel that way sometimes too.But with five months to go until we leave the EU, we have already reached agreement on the vast majority of our exit deal.What became clear at last week’s meeting in Brussels is that the very last stages of the talks are going to be the hardest of all.This includes dealing with the so-called “backstop”: making sure that, no matter what our new relationship with Europe looks like, there will be no hard border between Northern Ireland and Ireland.I’ve been very clear that this must be achieved without creating any kind of border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK – doing so would undermine our precious Union and put at risk the hard-won peace.So I am working closely with my counterparts in Europe to explore every possible solution to the border issue.Does that mean I think this negotiation will get tougher before we reach our goal  YesDo I have some long and dficult days ahead  I’m sure I do.But what I’m thinking about is not how hard it all is today.I’m thinking about the prize that lies before us tomorrow about the great opportunities the Government will help open up for you once we clear the last few hurdles.As we enter the final, crucial phase of the talks there will undoubtedly be some unexpected challenges to which we must rise.But the finish line is in sight. And I am more determined than ever that we will get there together, with a Brexit deal that’s right for you, right for your family and right for our country.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: go vape e cigs better than regular cigarettes
story: But it isn’t.They also think that because you are inhaling nicotine in the vapour of e-cigarettes you are just as likely to get lung cancer as you would smoking tobacco.You are not.There are also worries that vaping will act as a gateway for young people, who have never smoked, to progress to traditional cigarettes and ruin their health as a result.They are fears, too, that it will “normalise” smoking again just when public health campaigns are managing to help more people permanently quit smoking than ever before.All the evidence, however, says that this just is not the case.Don’t get me wrong, as a doctor I’d prefer itnobody smoked OR vaped.Years ago, as medical students, who should have known better, many of us smoked a little — often to disguise the awful, lingering smell of the cadavers we had to dissect in the anatomy room.But we soon stopped when we saw with our own eyes what the long-term effects of smoking did to the human body.In the Pathology Museum we would see a nice healthy pink lung sat pickled in a jar of formaldehyde right next to another lung, black with tar and soot from smoking, at the centre of which was a hard, pearly white grapefruit-sized knuckle of cancer with tentacles reaching out into other adjacent organs including the liver and brain.Smoking kills.Later, as qualied doctors on the wards, we saw the horrendous consequences of it.People who could not breathe without oxygen tanks, people suffering heart attacks or strokes, or undergoing amputations or voicebox removal for throat cancer.We saw — and still see — the damage done to unborn babies of expectant mothers, who remain addicted, and the increased risk of chest and ear infections from passive smoking, and meningitis and leukaemia in infants, who live in smoking households.The medical evidence is irrefutable. Smoking tobacco is bad news.But vaping is dferent.You heat up a solution called an e-liquid, which typically contains nicotine, a propellant called propylene glycol and or vegetable glycerin and flavourings.What you don’t do is burn tobacco or produce tar or carbon monoxide — two of the most harmful elements of all in tobacco smoke.Sure, some vapes may contain a fraction of some of the harmful chemicals found in cigarette smoke, but they are present at much lower levels,detectable at all.So are they safe  According to all the international medically-reviewed evidence from such expert organisations as Public Health England, the Royal Colleges of Physicians and General Practitioners, the British Medical Association and Cancer Research UK, e-cigarettes are at least  per cent safer than traditional cigarettes.The American Cancer Society and the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine both agree with them.Yes, the nicotine, of course, is addictive. But so what  So is caffeine, even eating.Contrary to popular belief, nicotine does not give you cancer and it is relatively harmless generally.Apparently only  per cent of the population know this.Happily, there is no evidence of harm to other people from vaping and,used instead of nicotine replacement gum or patches, may even help expectant mums remain smoke-free in the long term.As a doctor I don’t want any young person or non-nicotine user to try vaping. Ever. Period.As it happens, regular use of e-cigs among “never” smokers is still very rare at just . per cent.But look at what they’ve done to help tobacco smokers quit.In the UK, .million vapers have quit smoking completely and more than , have given up both smoking and vaping.In fact, this is Britain’s most popular method of quitting with two-thirds stopping successfully when used alongside professional stop-smoking NHS support.In this country we have some of the strictest regulations in the world.E-cigs are subject to minimum standards of quality and safety as well as clear packaging and labelling requirements.All ingredients have to be notied, advertising is prohibited in media such as television, newspapers and magazines, it is illegal to sell them to under s and to adults intending to pass them on to under s.That is responsible regulation whichever way you look at it.This month’s national Stoptober campaign recommends using e- cigarettes as a stop-smoking aid andit helps some of the million smokers in the UK kick the habit for good then perhaps doctors like me will see fewer people in our surgeries struggling to breath or devastated by a cancer diagnosis.AndI see any ex-smoking patients of mine having a quiet vape outside my surgery door, I shall give them a heartfelt pat on the back and cherish the fact that there will be one less nasty fag end polluting the street.NICOTINE contained in e-liquids is a highly addictive substance that raises blood pressure and spikes your adrenalin, increasing the chances of having a heart attack.This is particularly worrying as we see a number of iniduals who are constantly vaping, especially as it is seen as more convenient and cost-effective than lighting up a cigarette, as well as being considered more socially acceptable to vape indoors.While vaping appears to be safer than cigarettes, the truth is that it hasn’t been around long enough for us to know the potential damage it can cause to our health.The long-term effects of the chemicals contained in e-liquids haven’t been examined.However, I have looked into ious research that has been carried out on certain e-liquids that were found to contain substances that can cause damage to the immune system and are linked to other health conditions such as cancer.Vaping isn’t great for your oral health either.It’s common for vaping to cause a dry mouth, and I’ve met a number of iniduals who have developed oral thrush, most likely caused by vaping.Although nicotine does not have a colour, it becomes yellow when combined with oxygen which could lead to tooth discolouration.As nicotine is a vasocon-strictor, it limits blood flow in oral tissue, which can cause gum disease and bad breath.As time goes on, I am reading new research which proves vaping has a negative effect on health.To what extent, only time will tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: this morning universal credit single mum debt school uniforms
story: Stacey Gleave told ITVs This Morning that Brits on benefits were left with no safety net when they went on to the new system - as they have to wait five weeks to get a payment.She said she was forced into arrears when she went onto Universal Credit and still owes hundreds which she now cant pay off.People are having literally to live out of food banks, she told the programme. The problem for us is that we have been left with no safety net.In between we are left with nothing, youve got no back up behind you.Those who transfer onto Universal Credit are offered advance loans, which have steep repayment rates that come out of their next payment.Stacey says shes £ in debt since transferring over, and has been left in arrears.And since her kid moved school, she hasnt even been able to afford his new unorm.He was coming home and asking me why he was dferent... the real reason was I couldnt afford the unorm, she admitted.Luckily Stacey has been able to borrow money from her family to keep her going, but now owes them hundreds of pounds.It just adds all on to your debt, she says. Debt puts a big hold on you, it plays a big part in your le.Every day you wake up with the worries... What can you do to get out of it  There is nothing.Shes also been forced to controversial rent-to-own firm BrightHouse, which provides goods with sky-high interest rates.Customers are lured in by what the firm calls “affordable weekly repayments” - which might be something like £ a week for a flash Samsung TV.But the plans can go on for years, by which time you may have ended up paying more than double for your goods, as high lighted in our Stop the Credit Rip-Off campaignApply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently, or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website.The Sun revealed last week how families on Universal Credit are being forced to turn to payday loans to make ends meet.The Governments new flagship benefits system has been beset with problems since it started being rolled out across the country.It takes five weeks for the first payment to come through on Universal Credit, but some have been left waiting for months after that.Ministers are being urged to plug the gap in funding Universal Credit in next weeks Budget, so the millions that are yet to be transferred over wont lose out.The DWP says the vast majority of people on Universal Credit are satisfied, and their test and learn approach means that any problems are continuously being ironed out.

title: karren brady on women at work
story: I wanted to stop her right there and ask: “What on earth are you sorry about  Why don’t you know your worth “Why don’t you have ­confidence in the contribution you make ”It left me wondering why so many talented and competent women lack confidence at work to get the best out of their job. Why do they not get paid what they are worth to their company, and why are so many overlooked for promotion The sad fact is that for every £ men earn, women make just  pence.Just over one in ten women negotiated their starting salary, while more than half of all men haggle with their boss before they have even started work.When women do ask for more pay, they are  per cent less likely to get a raise. Andthey do receive a wage increase it will be  per cent less than men get.Sadly, it is common in business that women are often viewed as weak or unable to cope. And once we think about or start a family, we become toxic to employers.I receive hundreds of direct messages on social media from women asking: “How do I get a pay rise  How do I get noticed at work  How can I get promoted  How can I get on after maternity leave ”So now I am launching Get What You Want, a series of online masterclasses and podcasts covering everything from getting promoted to dealing with the word no, overcoming challenges, negotiating pay, writing a fantastic CV and nailing an interview.It will also cover baby-proofing careers, as well as becoming a super-mum after maternity leave.A lot of women have skills but just lack confidence. As women, we don’t shout about our wins enough for fear we will appear arrogant, even though men talk about them all the time.Here are some of my tips to winning at work.When people say: “I hate my job” I always ask: “Why are you telling me  I can’t do anything about it.”YOU have to do something. Sit down and work out what it is you don’t like about the position and set yourself a task of getting a new one.Be very dedicated and very professional and excel when you get to the interview.Many people don’t realise that when you are invited for an interview it is because they believe you can do the job.The secret is convincing them that you can do the job better than anyone .You should be able to talk about your specialist subject, which is yourself.People find it very dficult to list all the things they have done really well in a professional way to show good examples of why they can do the job.Opening a negotiation is all about knowing your worth.And knowing your value is really about your self-worth. They are totally linked.Write down all the things where you have made a big ­contribution, all the things that you have changed and made a dference, how you have added value. Put together testimonials to really back up what you have done.Then work out what more you want to do, because going above and beyond your job description is very important.Take out all the emotion, go in and lay out for your boss the facts of what you’ve contributed to the organisation.Sometimes people can be very passive. They say: “I’ll go along with what everyone  agrees with.”They want to avoid conflict. They don’t really think their opinion is as important as other people’s, so they are simply giving others a licence to ignore them.Learn to say no. Say: “I don’t really have the time butI can make the time I can do it for you.” Otherwise you become like a human sponge. Don’t let them take advantage.Employers take advantage of women’s lack of confidence, especially a mother ing from maternity leave. Many feel so grateful to have a job that they tend to put up with almost anything.Eleven per cent of new mothers report that they have been dismissed or made redundant where others in their workplace were not, or were treated so poorly they felt they had to leave.That means as many as , women are losing their jobs each year.Have a really clear plan of how you will manage at home and manage work. Get your partner to do his share  — and by that I mean half.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says may transition period
story: It is a trap, designed to keep us locked in to the EU racket.There’s nothing unreasonable about what Mrs May demanded yesterday — a backstop with a definite end date.Tusk, Barnier and Juncker will no doubt tell us it’s impossible.They will say “non” to any proposal we come up with, until the final seconds tick on the Brexit clock.The PM must hold her nerve. Because when it suits them, it’s amazing how many times the EU has shown a sudden flexibility.They are more than happy to break their sacred rules when it’s politically useful.They should be fining Italy for their illegal budget — but won’t, because it would stir a hornet’s nest of anti-EU feeling in a founder member.Brussels’ leaders do at least seem to understand we’re coming to the crunch.Unlike Leo Varadkar, the talkative Irish PM who is yet to see a microphone he didn’t like or miss an opportunity to undermine the UK.While our PM is giving statements in the Commons, this wannabe statesman is busy making jokes on Twitter about bailing Britain outBrexit goes badly.Ditch the jokes, Leo. There’ll be nothing funny for the Irish economyyour cack-handed comedy routine stops you trading with your closest neighbour.It’s getting serious. The PM knows that, and has done everything possible to get a deal.Now it’s Brussels’ turn.HAS the sun finally come out in Hundred Acre Wood Eeyore Chancellor Philip Hammond is reportedly considering a tax cut for struggling High Street businesses in next week’s Budget.About time too. Shops and pubs have been on the sharp end of business rate hikes, with many left at death’s door.A tax break would be a welcome sticking plaster, but in truth the rates system needs root and branch reform.The Chancellor must start on the second half of the High Street puzzle, too.Taxing the tech giants should be a Budget priority.MPs cannot be allowed to mark their own homework on bullying in Parliament.The evidence of a toxic culture in the House of Commons is compelling. The medieval process to deal with complaints simply cannot stand.The hypocrisy of MPs, who interfere in workplaces across the country on a daily basis, is staggering.The insufferable Speaker John Bercow has shown no appetite to give Commons staff the rights they deserve.Parliament must act.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keira knightley disney ban jane moore opinion
story: Sigh. Ms Knightley, who adds, “Rescue yourself,” clearly feels she is protecting daughter Edie by banning something that doesn’t concur with her own off-the-shelf, Poundland version of what feminism should be.But what she’s in danger of doing is wilfully nurturing a potential “snowflake” who, rather than develop the critical thinking skills that allow healthy debate, will simply stick their fingers in their ears and cry foul when they see or hear something that dfers from their own world view.Keira, tonight’s homework is to really readCinderella and analyse it.Look past the Disney-esque cute rodents, pretty frocks and glass slippers and instead dig a little deeper to ­appreciate the original’s narrative of how hope can turn unjust oppression into ­triumphant reward.Cinderella is a young woman who has not only suffered the loss of her loving father, but now faces a letime of abuse from an uncaring stepmother and her equally unpleasant daughters.But instead of sitting in the ashes ­waiting unquestioningly for whatever fate might have in store for her, she remains resolutely ­optimistic and decides to secretly defy her nemesis by gatecrashing a hot-ticket party to which she hasn’t been invited.Now that’s girl power.Ultimately, she “‘rescues” herself by proactively going to the ball where, instead of abuse, she experiences the redemptive qualities of love and kindness.They just happen to come in the form of a handsome prince.In the same week, Kristen Bell — who coincidentally voices Anna in the Disney film Frozen — found herself caught up in the slipstream of Keira’s PC virtue signalling after reportedly saying that Snow White gives young girls the wrong ­message about consent “because you cannot kiss someonethey’re sleeping”.Except Kristen’s comment was taken out of context and she’s got the balance right.Because what she actually said was that she reads the story with her two ­daughters, aged five and three, then asks them: “Don’t you think it’s weird that Snow White didn’t ask the old witch why she needed to eat the apple ” before starting up a conversation about the dos and don’ts of taking food from strangers.Or, “Don’t you think that it’s weird that the prince kisses Snow White without her permission ” to float an almost subliminal, age-appropriate understanding of what does and doesn’t constitute ­consent.Kristen isn’t banning tales of old, she’s using them to stimulate discussions.In other words, teaching her children the vital le skills of critical thinking — dictionary definition: “the objective analysis and evaluation of an issue in order to form a judgment” — and being able to rationally debate that judgment with someone whose view might dfer from your own.Attempting to sanitise a child’s world by airbrushing history will hinder, not help them.Instead, wield history’s lessons as a tool to educate.Cinderella was of its time and now the Disney pendulum has seemingly swung the other way to depict a world where all the central characters are feisty, opinionated young women who power-kick their way through le.But how will Keira’s daughter know how far the depiction of Disney ­princesses has comeshe’s not allowed to see where they’ve been ONE morning last week, I spent a glorious couple of hours walking around Westminster Abbey.Buried or commemorated there are, among others, more than , great Britonsincluding Sir Isaac Newton, Jane Austen, Noel Coward, Charles Darwin, the Bronte sisters, Clement Attlee, Charles Dickens, David Livingstone, Stephen Hawking and, of course, the grave of the unknown warrior, buried on November ,  “in honour of the many multitudes who during the Great War of - gave the most that man can give . . . le itself.”My mother works at the Abbey as a “blue-gowner” – the volunteer guides there to answer any questions not covered by the electronic headsets – and, while showing us the ft by ft grave of poet Ben Jonson, who is the only person there to be buried upright, she was approached by a couple of earnest-looking women in their early twenties.Amid such a rich seam of history, rigorous intellect and achievement, what did they ask “Excuse me, where did David Beckham sit for the royal wedding ”THE number of stay-at-home dads has dropped to the lowest level in five years.Experts reckon it could be due to men “growing tired” of the tough job of raising kids.Proof,needed, might be the glassy-eyed expression of Bond actor Daniel Craig,  just six weeks after we Rachel Weisz gave birth to their daughter.He never looks this knackered when he’s jumping off buildings and dodging bullets.Stay-at-home parenthood can be isolating, sometimes dull, frequently thankless and relentlessly bloody exhausting. Only the strong survive it.THANKS to Ryanair’s ­astonishing failure to act when a passenger racially abused Windrush immigrant Delsie Gayle on one of its flights, the man will likely escape prosecution because of jurisdictional issues once a plane takes off from one country’s airspace to another.Instead, he is likely only to be banned from ever travelling on Ryanair again.Which, as plenty of the budget airline’s past ­customers might tell you, could equally be regarded as a blessing rather than a punishment.COMEDIAN Seann Walsh and his Strictly partner Katya Jones have survived the dreaded dance-off to, presumably, jive another day.Because, let’s face it, since that snog, the Strictly bosses are ­rapidly running out of drearily chaste dances to give them.Last weekend it was the unsexy Charleston, ­performed in equally unsexy “Where’s Wally” outfits that virtually screamed “nothing to see here”. Then this weekend it was a faintly ­ludicrous, undeniably platonic quickstep that saw them trotting around the floor like a couple of hyperactive show ponies.Assuming the sizzling Argentine tango is, er, strictly no-go, whatever next  A jive in burkas  A Viennese waltz in sackcloths Not least from Tom himself, perhaps, whose first we Mimi Rogers bemoaned the lack of intimacy in their union because, she claims, he wanted to be a monk and “thought he had to be celibate to maintain the purity of his instrument, but my instrument needed tuning, and we had to split.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rome subway football fans crushed escalator
story: Horrying footage shows the moment dozens were injured after the mal at Romes Repubblica underground station.Part of one victims foot was cut off in the incident ahead of CSKA Moscows Champions League match with Roma, according to La Repubblica.One person told the paper: I just witnessed a scene from the apocalypse.Witnesses quoted by police said Russian fans were singing and jumping on the escalator shortly before it collapsed.Terrying screams can be heard in the footage as scores of people were sent hurtling towards the bottom.Some passengers were pulled to safety while others scrambled over the central reservation but many were crushed in the mechanism.Reports on the number of people injured y, with the Russian embassy in Italy saying up to  were hurt, with  taken to hospital.The local prefects office put the number of injured at , whereas La Repubblica said  were hurt – seven seriously.More than  firefighters have been scrambled to the station.Rome provincial fire chief Giampietro Boscaino said: The scene that we found was people piled up at the bottom of the escalator.People one on the top of the other looking for help.They had ious injuries caused by the escalator that was twisted, therefore serious injuries.A police spokesman told Russian news agency RIA: A group of CSKA fans were going down into the station.At that moment the escalator collapsed.One photo shared on social media appears to show blood and broken metal at the bottom of the maling escalator.ANSA news agency quoted city transport agency officials as saying maintenance is carried out on metro system escalators every month.Meanwhile, a Russian fan was stabbed during clashes between supporters near the Stadio Olimpico.Two other travelling Moscow fans were also said to have been hurt in the melee.Police were deployed with water cannons to break up the violence.

title: meghan markle paid university fees
story: During a trip to the University of the South Pacic the glowing duchess seemed to contradict her dads claims that he paid for her tuition.Meghan said: As a university graduate, I know the personal feeling of pride and excitement that comes with attending university.I am also fully aware of the challenges of being able to afford this level of schooling for many people around the world – myself included.It was through scholarships, financial aid programmes and work-study where my earnings from a job on campus went directly towards my tuition - that I was able to attend university.And, without question, it was worth every effort.The comments have got online tongues wagging that the duchess, who attended Northwestern University in Illinois, may have been having a sly pop at her dad.Thomas Markle has in the past claimed that he paid Meghans £,-a-year tuition after winning £, on a lottery.He told previously told the Daily Mail: When Meghan was , she moved back in with me up until she was  and went to college.I was having my good years then, making good money, and could afford to give her the best, with a good school, good education, good home.She became the woman that she is today thanks to everything I did for her.But fans have taken to Twitter to call his claims into question suggesting that the duchess was throwing shade at her dad." data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   unnamed-file.png stripallw" "" width""  " data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   unnamed-file.png stripallw" "" width"" A tweeter calling herself Liberian girl tweeted: Did Meghan just clap back to her Liar sister and disgraceful father in that speech without even mention their names Neri replied: Yup! was being given a tour when security forces intervened.Harry, , had earlier laid a wreath and met Fijian war veterans without his pregnant we.Meghan who has already skipped events in Australia, arrived later in the day to give her first speech of the royal tour.The couple were met by musicians and cheering crowds as they arrived to mark the universitys th anniversary.The mum-to-be arrived wearing a pink Figue Frederica printed dress and flowers in her hair, with Harry in a blue shirt.In her speech Meghan added: Everyone should be afforded the opportunity to receive the education they made a trip to Colo-i-Suva Forest Park with Meghan heading to the British High Commissioners Residence and Suva Market.She was rushed through her visit to the indoor market in Fijis capital over apparent concerns about the locations security.Earlier in the day Harry left a touching personal note during a wreath laying ceremony.The duke laid the wreath on a hook on the memorial stone with a note reading: In grateful memory of those who made the ultimate sacrice in the service of their country.Loloma kei na masu .He then went to talk to Fijian war veterans, including a number who had served with the British Armed Forces.The duke spoke of his admiration for the Fijian service personnel at the black tie dinner hosted by the president on Tuesday night.In his speech, he said: Your soldiers fought with the British Armed Forces during the First and Second World Wars and continue to serve alongside our soldiers to this day, with more than , Fijians currently serving.I must emphasise my respect, admiration and camaraderie with the Fijian soldiers that I served with in Afghanistan. We trained together, we fought together, and most importantly we laughed together.

title: germany post brexit eu contribution
story: The cash will cover lost earnings from British taxpayers as well as providing new funding to battle ongoing crises like migration.It will take Berlin’s gross contribution to the EU budget, before the money it gets back in grants, up to a staggering £ billion a year.The revelations, from a finance ministry report on the next EU budget, have prompted fury at German taxpayers being milked for cash by Brussels.Eckhardt Rehberg, a senior MP in Angela Merkel’s ruling Christian Democratic Union, told newspaper Bild: “Europe is not suffering from too little money.”Britain is the second biggest net contributor to the EU budget and Brexit will leave a £ billion black hole in the bloc’s finances.Germany already stumps up over a fth of all Brussels’ cash, with its share set to rise further after our exit.And those calculations are based on the UK paying the £ billion orce bill, which will only happenthe two sides reach an agreement.The EU’s budget Commissioner, Gunther Oettinger, has admitted to The Sun he has no “plan B” forthe UK quits without a deal. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cabinet meltdown if brexit goes wrong
story: Theresa May’s top table endured a heated exchange of views during a Brexit discussion yesterday as tensions boiled over.Revelation of the fresh dust up came as the PM prepares to confront all Tory backbenchers in a showdown meeting tonight.Ministers yesterday ided into two camps over how to unlock a deal with Brussels during an update from the PM on last week’s failed EU summit.Pro-EU Cabinet Office minister David Lidington called for more compromises to avoid the sort of economic meltdown that hit the UK when it span out of the ERM in September .The  year-old Tory veteran insisted that as the only member of the Cabinet who was an MP them, they “couldn’t have that level of chaos again”.He was backed by Justice Secretary David Gauke and Chancellor Philip Hammond.But Brexit supporter and Attorney Geoffrey Cox was said to have used “colourful barrister language” to warn that the Irish backstop could leave the UK trapped forever under the EU’s thumb in “Dante’s first circle of hell”.Former May loyalist, Treasury Chief Secretary Liz Truss, also backed Mr Cox’s call for a watertight mechanism to escape any temporary customs union backstop.And there was also a row about Mrs May’s proposal to extend the transition period by a few more months.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt lead the attacks on the idea, floated as a way of ducking any customs ides being imposed on the UK.And Energy minister Claire Perry lashed out at former Brexit boss David Davis fore being “on manoeuvres” to oust Mrs May.The PM will try to try to face down a large backbench rebellion against her over Brexit with an unscheduled address to the weekly meeting of Tory MPs’  Committee tonight.Party chairman Brandon Lewis was due to address the room, but has been bounced after Mrs May personally requested she step in.But critics suggested she only made the move after Chief Whip Julian Smith declared he was confident of pulling off a choreographed show of loyalty for her.A rumour spread like wildfire across Westminster yesterday that a no confidence vote in the Tory leader was imminent as the required number of her MPs –  - had submitted letters calling for one.But  Committee chairman Sir Graham Brady quashed the claim, telling friends that he had “no plans to go to No today” and was going about his normal business.Home Secretary Amber Rudd also rallied to Mrs May’s defence to dub a leadership election in the middle of the Brexit negotiations as a “total indulgence” and a “huge mistake”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kate middleton princess diana tiara queen buckingham palace
story: Kate, , joined husband Prince William, , and other senior royals for a spectacular dinner hosted in honour of King Willem-Alexander and Queen Maxima of the Netherlands.In keeping with regal protocol, female members of both the Dutch and British royal families wore ball gowns and tiaras.The duchess, who was appearing at her third state banquet, wore a dusty kingfisher blue Alexander McQueen gown - and of course that diamond and pearl Cambridge Lovers Knot tiara favoured by Princess Diana.Kate has also worn it to the Chinese state banquet in  and the Spanish state banquet last year. But it seemed she was out-blinged by Queen Maxima who was wearing an incredible diamond Stuart tiara.In tribute to the close links between the British and Dutch royal families, she perhaps chose to wear this fabulously jewelled ornamental band in tribute to the historical bonds between the neighbouring countries. The large stone was originally bought in late th century by the British monarch William III, also Netherlandss Prince of Orange, for his we Queen Mary II.Pinned to her left shoulder was the Elizabeth II Family Order is a jewel encased image of the Queen on a chartreuse yellow ribbon.Notably Her Majesty, , spoke publicly about Brexit for the first time.She said: “As we look toward a new partnership with Europe” the values shared by the UK and the Netherlands are our greatest assets”.She added that as innovators, traders and internationalists we look with confidence to the future.The Queen, who remains impartial in political matters of her realm, opted to emphasise the qualities needed by the UK and its closet European neighbours going forward as her government and parliament continued to be deeply ided by the issue of Brexit.Earlier, in a speech to both Houses of Parliament, King Willem-Alexander urged the UK Government to lt the shadow of uncertainty hanging over Dutch nationals living in Britain and Northern Ireland after Brexit.In his address at the Buckingham Palace dinner, with the UKs Prime Minister Theresa May seated nearby, King Willem-Alexander said: At present, a lot of attention is focused on the technical side of Brexit. Thats understandable and necessary.But in the midst of all that complexity we should not lose sight of the greater narrative that continues to bind us.The greater narrative of freedom, openness and cooperation. Of growth and a prosperity whose fruits are enjoyed by all.The Queen told the Netherlands head of state: I recall the state visit of your grandmother Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard in , when I spoke of how our nations close understanding and relationship would become increasingly important as a new configuration of Europe was emerging.As we look toward a new partnership with Europe, it is our shared values and commitment to each other, that are out greatest asset, and demonstrate that even through change, our enduring alliance remains strong, and as innovators, traders and internationalists we look with confidence to the future.In her speech, the Queen also praised the close links between the UK and Holland which greatly contributes to the economic and cultural le of Britain.She added: The Netherlands are one of the United Kingdoms largest European investors. We have a thriving Dutch community, and artistic and sporting exchanges are at an all-time high.King Willem-Alexander reiterated comments made before about regretting the UKs decision to leave the EU, but he respected the decision of the British people.He went on to personally praise the Queen, highlighting her now famous appearance in the London  Olympics opening ceremony, describing her as the most fearless Bond Girl ever for her cameo role alongside  played by Daniel Craig.King Willem-Alexander also told the Queen and her banquet: In recent decades, you have seen your country, Europe and the world change enormously.The world looks to you as a trusted beacon in the midst of upheaval.Your ability to keep in touch with the times is striking.Meanwhile down under, Meghan Markle revealed her maternity wardrobe would be just as stunning as her pre-pregnancy style as she attended a banquet in Fiji. Along with Prince Harry, the mum-to-be attended a reception and dinner hosted by the island countrys president and opted for a breathtaking full- gown.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex arrived in Fiji earlier today as part of their -day royal tour.And -year-old Meghan couldnt stop cradling her growing baby bump as the pair attended a Fiji state banquet at the Grand Pacic Hotel.The Duchess looked beautul for the event and chose to wear a £, cape dress by London-based designer, Safiyaa.The blue gown is said to be in tribute to Fiji, whose flag is the same shade of blue.

title: napoleon tribute act emmanuel macron sun says
story: On one side, Irish PM Leo Varadkar is more a comedian than he is a statesman, though it’s not a high bar to clear.On the other, Emmanuel Macron, a Napoleon tribute act whose stature is matched only by his collapsing poll ratings ­— and who is using tough talk on Brexit to distract from trouble at home.But Mini Manu’s threats ring hollow.Does he honestly think French businesses will thank himhe brings a huge chunk of the £billion-plus trade between our two countries to a halt Does he honestly think French consumers are so annoyed about our decision to leave that they’ll want lorries blocking their motorways and supermarket shelves empty But Macron’s desire to wreak havoc on the UK economy as a Brexit punishment betrays the Continent’s fear that an unleashed Britain would leave the EU in the dust.We have no desire for our Government to enter a trade war.If Britain goes without a deal — and there’s every chance — then we will show Europe what they’re missing with tax cuts and a red tape bonfire that will supercharge the economy.A sensible French leader would welcome a deal that works for both sides.Time for l’enfant terrible to grow up.GOOD luck to Sir James Dyson in Asia.His new Singapore plant will give his thriving British firm a foothold in the world’s fastest-growing car market.And it seems to have escaped the Remainers crowing that Brexit-backer Sir James has chosen to build abroad that — by their logic — we’d have to boot Nissan out of Sunderland.Brexit is about building a free trading Britain. That means being a part of a global economy. One in which the Japanese can build cars in the North East, American outfits can trade in the City and, yes, navy blue British passports can be made in France.Protectionism is a race to the bottom.BRITAIN now has the fourth lowest rate of home ownership in the EU.It is a damning indictment of decades of failed housing policy. Next week’s Budget is a chance for a radical sea change to ensure our property-owning democracy survives for generations.Don’t blow it, Chancellor.MPs shouldn’t have to march on Downing Street to end the witch-hunt against Northern Ireland veterans.But the PM and Cabinet must listen.The disgraceful pursuit must stop.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mh370 wreckage claims bruma google earth
story: Taken from Google Earth, the object appears to be shaped like a large passenger plane - sparking a wild theory it could be the missing jet itself.MH vanished in March  during a flight from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing with  people on board.The plane was never found despite a search that cost hundreds of millions and sparked one of the greatest aviation mysteries in history.The UK-based sleuth, who works in aviation security, told The Sun Online: It appears to be the shape of a plane in the water.That was one of its rough radar positions. title: face baby scan mum miscarried child
story: Jane Evans’ says her children have also spoken to their “big brother” when they were toddlers, despite not knowing she had a miscarriage.The -year-old was devastated when she lost her first baby at just ten weeks, but she was luckily able to get pregnant very soon after.When the expectant mum had her D scan for her second pregnancy, she was amazed at how many friends said they spotted a second face in the photo.Jane believes that the little face was her miscarried child watching over her unborn daughter Lydia to “keep her safe”.The beautician’s two children, Lydia and Jenson Randell, grew up talking to their “big brother” before they knew about the miscarriage.A home video also eerily shows Lydia dancing around the living room and saying “this is what big brother does”.Whenever Jane saw Lydia giggling and laughing she always said she was chatting with her “big brother”.Jane, of Hinckley, Leicester, said her two kids both started talking to “big brother” when they were two.She said: “My daughter and my son all used to play with big brother. They were about two at the time when it first began.Lydia used to laugh and giggle and I would ask who she was talking to and she would say big brother.I always thought it was the boy that I lost. Before they even had any knowledge of the miscarriage or any badness in the world, they were talking to their big brother.They were only toddlers so I hadnt mentioned anything about the baby I lost.”Lydia is now  and Jenson is seven, and now Jane wondersher third child Marty Gascoyne will also start talking to her miscarried child too.She added: Its strange, both of them were always talking to their big brother so I am waiting for my youngest now to start talking to someone.Im waiting to seeMarty starts doing it as he is two now. But hes only a half brother as he has a dferent daddy so it may not happen. I dont know, well just wait and see.Her partner tried to explain away the face in the D scan as a reflection, but Jane is confident it is her children’s “big brother” watching over their siblings.She decided to share the photo of the D scan in hopes that other parents who have experienced the same thing can take comfort in knowing they are not alone.She said: “Ive always pointed it out to people like my sisters and so on and they always thought it was strange that Lydia used to do that. But then Jenson started doing it as well.Ive always felt Ive got a little somebody following me around andits true then it is lovely.“It brings some comfort to know that the baby is still there with us.If its not true, it doesnt matter as Ill never know either way anyway.“Its just nice to think that.
