title: single mums reveal true horror
story: NewsSingle mums reveal true horror of Universal Credit in damning testimony to ParliamentWomen told how the benefit left them with £, bills, fines and a £-a-day survival rate. Heres what they told MPs - and why it mattersShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video mums-descend-parliament-tell-how-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave group of single mums today revealed the true chaos of Universal Credit in damning testimony to Parliament. Women told how the Tories six-in-one benefit left them with pound, childcare bills, late payment fines and even being kicked out of nursery. One mum said she was forced to turn down her dream job because it would have left her with just pound a day for food, bills, nappies and petrol. Thuto Mali, mum to a two-year-old boy, confessed: We were at the food bank last Christmas because it got that bad. It’s not that I don’t want to work - it’s just that work doesnt pay. Heres what they told MPs - and why it matters.  The four women gave evidence to the Work and Pensions Committee as UC - already rolled out to .million people, and due to hit million by December  - pushes the poor to rent arrears and food banks. Theresa May is facing huge pressure to pump more money into the benefit, which has been bundled up with billions in welfare cuts since it launched in . So far campaigners have focused on this and other problems with the benefit, like the five-week wait for payment. But today the single mums talked about a dferent side to the story - how Universal Credit affects childcare. Working parents on UC can claim back % of their nursery fees. Yet they have to pay up-front first, and claim the money back later.  The policy saddled mum-of-two Vikki Waterman with a pound, bill which she had to wait five weeks to be paid back. The -year-old was also fined pound by her nursery because a late benefit payment meant she was two days behind paying for childcare. She told MPs: We dont want to sit at home when we didnt plan to be single parents. We shouldnt be penalised for that. That is not what we are here for. We want to be able to go to work and to provide for our own families, and at the minute it seems asthere is a roadblock everywhere we turn.  Hairdresser and mum-of-three Gaynor Rowles, from Heywood, Greater Manchester, was forced to pay up-front costs for her three-year-old twins. It’s pound per week. Where do I find that money from ” she said. Describing how she was just pound. a week better off in work, I’ve changed as a person. I’m not my normal happy self. Its quite sad really. Theres more people out there who are worse off than me. Ive got good family, good friends and good support. The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. Thuto Mali revealed her little boy was even suspended from nursery. “I was paying, I think, half or three quarters of it and his dad was supposed to pay the other - it didn’t quite happen, she said. So I got whacked with an pound bill. She said she was forced to turn down a job with a pound, salary because after paying pound, a month for a full-time nursery spot for her son she would be left with pound a month to cover bills. Thats effectively pound a day, she said. Work didnt pay for us.  Nail technician Lucy Collins, from Manchester, told MPs she left her job in the police because she couldnt fit shts around her kids, aged  and . Only then did she discover the problems of being on Universal Credit. You just get passed from pillar to post, she said. It’s so complex. And to top it all off - its easier for the middle class  Astonishingly, MPs heard the system is more lenient on well-off parents than it is on people claiming benefits. People on Universal Credit must submit receipts and invoices on an online journal to ensure they get the money back. Dalia Ben-Galim, policy director at the charity Gingerbread, told MPs: Theres a very dferent burden of proof on more middle-class parents. You don’t need to submit receipts - you need to have a registered childcare provider.  The moneys in your account and you, as a parent, are able to transfer that directly. I think that is ideological - it’s an active decision that has been made. Shocked Tory MP Heidi Allen branded the double standard terrible. Committee chairman Frank Field added the whole system is middle-class management of money. It doesn’t take into accountyou have a daily wage or a weekly wage. What the DWP says  A Department for Work and Pensions spokeswoman said: We are doing more than ever before to support parents with the cost of childcare and by - we will be spending around a record pound billion on childcare support. Under Universal Credit, working parents can claim back up to % of eligible childcare costs, compared to % of costs covered under the previous legacy system. This is the highest level of support ever. Andsomeone has accepted an offer of paid work, they are eligible to be paid these costs for the month prior to starting work. This generous provision has been widely welcomed by stakeholders and is available in addition to an entitlement of up to  hours of free childcare.

title: theresa promises improve gagging order
story: NewsTheresa May promises to improve gagging order laws used to cover up abhorrent behaviourThe Prime Minister was responding to reports that a "leading businessman" had obtained an injunction to preventShareByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video labours-jess-phillips-questions-may-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May has promised to improve laws on gagging orders, after a court blocked a newspaper from reporting allegations about a company boss She said non-disclosure agreements were being used unethically, and criticised abhorrent behaviour in the workplace. But she said such agreements shouldnt stop whistleblowers from coming forward over sexual harassment. The Prime Minister was responding to reports that a leading businessman had obtained an injunction to prevent the Dailyrevealing alleged sexual harassment and racial abuse of staff. They said five employees of companies in the group had made allegations of discreditable conduct by the executive. In all five cases complaints had been compromised by settlement agreements under which substantial payments were made to the employees who had complained.  Both sides had undertaken to keep confidential the subject matter of complaints.At Prime Ministers Questions in the House of Commons, Labour MP Jess Phillips said: It seems that our laws allow rich and powerful men to pretty much do whatever they want as long as they can pay to keep it quiet.So does the Prime Minister support the Court of Appeals decision to back non-disclosure agreements which have been used to silence women who have been sexually harassed and others who have been racially abused  Mrs May replied: I cant comment on a particular case that is currently before the courts. What I will say, and what I have said previously, is that sexual harassment in the workplace is against the law. Such abhorrent behaviour should not be tolerated. She added: An employer that allows that harassment of women to go undealt-with is sending a message about how welcome they are and about their value in the workplace. So just as we wont accept any behaviour that causes people to feel intimidated or humiliated in the workplace, there must be consequences for failing to comply with the law. Non-disclosure agreements cannot stop people from whistle-blowing but it is clear some employers are using them unethically. The Government is going to bring forward measures for consideration for consultation to seek to improve the regulation around non-disclosure agreements and make it absolutely explicit to employees when a non-disclosure agreement does not apply or cannot be enforced.  Mrs Mays official spokesman later said that non-disclosure arrangements should never be used to cover up criminal activity. The Government began work earlier this year on measures to improve the regulation around NDAs to ensure that they are used in an ethical manner and for their intended purpose, said the spokesman. Further details will be revealed imminently when a consultation process is launched.A Labour spokesman said the party was committed to ensuring that it is nolonger legal to have non-disclosure agreements which prevent the disclosure of victimisation or harassment or discrimination.In August, High Court judge Mr Justice Haddon-Cave refused to gag the newspaper but the executive - identied in court papers as ABC - and managers at the two companies mounted a challenge. Master of the Rolls Sir Terence Etherton, Lord Justice Underhill and Lord Justice Henderson outlined their decision in a ruling published on Tuesday. In all five cases complaints had been compromised by settlement agreements under which substantial payments were made to the employees who had complained, they wrote.

title: universal credit isnt getting fixed
story: NewsopinionUniversal Credit isnt getting fixed for the Tories ideological reasons. It doesnt have to be like thisLib Dem leader Sir Vince Cable writes for the Mirror about the slow-motion disaster of Universal CreditShareCommentsBySir Vince Cable:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsopinionSir Vince Cable "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailYou would have to be hiding under a very large rock to not know about the serious problems affecting the roll-out of universal credit. The new benefit has been unravelled by deep cuts to its funding by the Conservatives combined with their stubborn unwillingness to fix glaring flaws in its design. The result is a slow-motion disaster which risks failing to achieve its goals while needlessly pushing tens of thousands of households into poverty. It doesn’t have to be like this. The Conservatives’ failure to competently implement Universal Credit should not blind us to its inherent merits. The Liberal Democrats supported UC in principle because we believed in its aim of simplying our convoluted welfare system and making work pay for those on benefits.  While the current Government’s handling of UC has left it on le support, Liberal Democrats argue that with a pause followed by some major reforms, the system could yet be salvaged. The first big problem with UC is a lack of money. Though initially designed to be more generous than the system it is replacing, in the  summer Budget the Conservatives cut around poundbillion per year from UC’s funding, making it in effect less generous. Many warned at the time of the impact the cuts would have on the poorest, which are only now beginning to be felt. According to the Joseph Rowntree Foundation – where I am giving a speech today - they are likely to push around , people into poverty by .  The second problem is a number of major design flaws which the Conservatives are refusing to fix for ideological reasons. The most well-known of these are the long waits - both for first payment and in-between payments - that are pushing many desperate households into indebtedness and food bank dependency. Another is UC’s policy of making claimants responsible for their housing benefit payments, which has led to a spike in rent arrears and a growing unwillingness of landlords to rent to people on UC. The Government argues that these design features will teach people to be responsible with their finances, but instead the Government should take responsibility and end the suffering it is inflicting on society’s most vulnerable.

title: ambulance worker told just months
story: NewsAmbulance worker told she had just months to live two days after her dream weddingAmbulance worker Julie Allen, nee Jones, married her partner Ian Allen but their happiness and plans for decade together was quickly shatteredShareCommentsByHannah Maltwood:,  OCT NewsJulie Allen, nee Jones, with her husband Ian Allen on their wedding day "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A bride was diagnosed with inoperable cancer - just two days after her dream wedding.Ambulance worker Julie Allen, nee Jones, married her partner Ian Allen but her happiness was quickly shattered. She had only been married  hours when she was was told she had pancreatic cancer - and had just months left to live. The only symptom she had experienced before the diagnosis was stomach pains and she was offered an ultrasound examination to be safe. Julie, who works as an Emergency Care Assistant, met Ian in the ambulance service and has helped hundreds of patients over the years. Many of them have already contributed to a fundraising page set up to help her.  She has been undergoing chemotherapy but due to the position of the tumor an operation has been deemed too risky. Julie, of Hayle, Cornwall, said she almost cancelled the ultra-sound operation as she felt completely fine. She added: After the ultrasound I got a call to say they had found a shadow. I wasnt worried. I didnt think it would be anything because I felt so good. Then, two days after my wedding, I got the diagnosis - it was pancreatic cancer. The first thing that went through my mind was that I would never get to celebrate my first wedding anniversary with Ian. It was hard. I thought I wouldnt be around for Christmases or my grandchildrens birthdays. So I actually went out and bought four years worth of cards for them all, in case I wasnt around. Every  minutes someone in the UK is diagnosed with a blood cancer, according to the non-profit advocacy group DKMS. This may be leukaemia, lymphoma or myeloma. Blood cancer is the third most common cause of cancer death in the UK. However, only one in three people with it - and in need of a transplant - will find a matching blood stem cell donor within their own family. Two in three need to look outside of this.Around  per cent of all donations are made through a method called peripheral blood stem cell . This is where blood is taken from one of the donor’s arms and a machine extracts the blood stem cells from it.The donor’s blood is then ed to them through their other arm. The outpatient procedure is typically completed in four to six hours. In  per cent of cases, donations are made through bone marrow collection. This is done while under general anaesthetic. To register as a potential donor, visit dkms.org.uk.Once youve received your home swab kit, it takes a few moments to swab. When you thenthe kit, you go on standby to help save a le. Now she is hoping that, by sharing her story so that others can be more aware, it could help more people catch the illness early and recognise symptoms. She added: They havent given me a set prognosis but the le expectancy for people with inoperable pancreatic cancer isnt long at all its about nine months.  Treliske said that due to where the tumour is, it is inoperable. So I started emailing every expert and professor I could find as I dont feel like I should be written off. I have been up to the Royal Free Hospital in London and spoken to a professor up there who has agreed to operate providing the tumour shrinks. I have contacted every clinical trial going. With Julie having to take time off work, covering the costs of travel to London, fees for any trials she gets accepted for and having also been given notice to leave her home, financial strains have taken their toll. Now, through an online fundraising page set up by one of Julies co-workers, Nicola Rashleigh, more than pound, has been raised to help Julie and her family. Donations have been made by friends, family, colleagues and people she has helped through her role as an emergency care assistant. Gran Julie said: When it snowed I was working with a paramedic and we were called out to an elderly woman, but the ambulance was a nightmare in the snow. We had to abandon it and go on foot. Her daughter donated. She wrote a message about how Id helped her mum. I was so touched. Its things like that that really humble you. She added: I cried because people have been so nice, strangers giving me money and writing messages.To donate visit here.

title: meghan markles baby bump appears
story: NewsWhy Meghan Markles baby bump appears so much bigger at nightPeople were surprised by how much her baby bump had grown when she appeared at a state dinner on the islandShareCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video meghan-markle-stuns-blue-dress-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are finding even more eyes on them than usual lately after they announced their baby news on the day they landed in Australia for a -day tour of Commonwealth countries.The couple have been out and about meeting the public in Australia and Fiji so far on their diary-busting trip, which has a whopping  official engagements. But what Meghan might be finding a bit odd is that all eyes are now on her stomach, which the mum-to-be has been sweetly cradling while at events. And people were surprised when her bump seemed to miraculously grow over the course of a day when the Duke and Duchess touched down in Fiji. Meghan, who is around four months pregnant, was seen wearing an elegant white dress to land on the island, and her bump wasnt that visible.  But when she changed into a stunning blue cape gown for a state dinner that evening, social media users went wild with confusion.  Emily Andrews, the Suns royal correspondent who is following the couple on the tour, said on the night of the state dinner: I also note that Meghan’s baby bump is getting bigger by the day! I swear it was not this big last week! I think it’s the clinging nature of the dress but she’s sure looking swell! Although the fact the dress is clinging to her - and the fact she is holding her bump - might make it appear larger, one doula thinks it might be down to a biological factor. Susanna Birch told Trimester Talk: At night time, your abdominal muscles are tired from holding your bump [and they] loosen as they grow more tired, which allows your bump to sit out further and appear larger.An obstetrician also told Mamamia that it could be down to bloating from having eaten over the course of the day.But another possible cause of womens bumps being bigger at night is the hormone progesterone, which is released from the placenta.  Dr Joseph Sgroi said: One of the things progesterone does, which is the primary hormone thats secreted from the placenta, is it actually slows down gut motility, so it slows down the transit time from when you eat something to when it comes out the other end. The hormone is thought to be an evolutionary advantage for pregnant women in days when there was not as much food available - so food digestion is slowed and they absorb all possible nutrients to pass on to their unborn baby. Dr Sgroi also believes Meghans bump is likely to look even bigger by the end of the tour - which is less than a week away - given it is thought she is around four months pregnant.  After about  weeks onwards, this uterus which is predominantly in the pelvis now starts to move to the tummy or the abdomen, and thats when you start to show more and more, he told Mamamia. He added that Meghan is at a time in pregnancy where a womans uterus is expanding at great knots and the changes may not be subtle. Meghan and Harrys baby is due in Spring .

story: NewsMum spots face of miscarried child in baby pregnancy scan - and claims kids speak to  angel big brotherJane Evans, , lost her first baby just  weeks into her pregnancy, but after going for a D scan during another pregnancy, was stunned to see two faces peering from the imageShareCommentsByAbigail OLearyDavid Keane:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video mum-believes-kids-speak-miscarried-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum claims she spotted the face of her miscarried baby in a pregnancy scan and even says her two children speak to their  angel big brother. Jane Evans, , was heartbroken when she lost her first baby just  weeks into her pregnancy. But, just weeks later, the beautician discovered she was pregnant, with now -year-old Lydia, and after going for a D scan, was stunned to see two faces peering from the image. Jane believes the second face in the scan is that of her miscarried baby, who watched over her daughter during pregnancy. Incredibly, Jane from Hinckley, Leicestershire, says her two children Lydia and Jenson Randell started speaking to their big brother without ever knowing he had existed. Spooky footage even shows little Lydia dancing and saying this is what big brother does while showing dance moves to her grandad.  Now Jane is waiting to seeher third child Marty will also be befriended by their invisible big brother. Jane said: I like to think that maybe the little baby that I lost is looking over my daughter and keeping her safe for me. Seeing that other little face in there with her did make me feel a little bit sad. But at the same time,I hadnt lost the baby that I lost, I wouldnt have Lydia now. It was quite comforting to know that someone was looking out for her. There are other photos in the D scan that show that area and the face is not there so it does make you wonder. And the face is looking in a completely dferent direction to the way to Lydia.  For me, I cant explain it. If someone can, thats lovely, but I cant explain how its got there. Jane had been working as a call handler at National Grid when she fell pregnant with her first child  years ago - but tragedy struck just  weeks into the pregnancy. Jane said: I had been pregnant and lost the baby at about  weeks. We went for a scan and it was definitely gone. But a couple of weeks later I still felt quite pregnant. The doctor said it must have been left over hormones and I did a test and it was negative. But I just knew, I knew I was pregnant again so I kept testing. A few days later I did another test and it was positive. I was elated. It was the best feeling ever. It was lovely. And when I had the D scan done, even my mum said she looked like an Evans. It was so lovely being able to see her face on there and knowing that she was well and that they had done all the tests to check she was healthy inside. It was only when Jane took the D of little Lydia into work that work pals pointed out the second face.  Jane said: It was only when I showed the picture to people at work that they said whats that there. I said I didnt know. They said it looked like I had another baby in there and askedI was sure I was not having twins. Obviously I said I was just having one - and I was. They pointed at the photo and I did think it was a bit... dferent. Looking at the photo, it just looks like a face looking in a completely dferent direction to the way my daughter is looking. Little Lydia was born three weeks early happy and healthy and is now  years old. However for years the youngster would speak to her imaginary friend who she called big brother, as did Janes second child Jenson, now seven.  Now Jane is wonderingher third child Marty Gascoyne will soon start talking to his phantom brother as he is now two years old. Jane said: My daughter and my son all used to play with big brother. They were about two at the time when it first began. Lydia used to laugh and giggle and I would ask who she was talking to and she would say big brother. I always thought it was the boy that I lost. Before they even had any knowledge of the miscarriage or any badness in the world, they were talking to their big brother. They were only toddlers so I hadnt mentioned anything about the baby I lost. Its strange, both of them were always talking to their big brother so I am waiting for my youngest now to start talking to someone. Im waiting to seeMarty starts doing it as he is two now. But hes only a half brother as he has a dferent daddy so it may not happen. I dont know, well just wait and see. Jane likes to think that her little baby still watches on and is bravely sharing the photo in the hope it may give other parents who experienced the same thing some comfort.  Jane said: My partner at the time said he thought it was a reflection but I dont know what it would be a reflection of in someones stomach. I just dont think he liked to think that way, but Ive always thought that way. Ive always pointed it out to people like my sisters and so on and they always thought it was strange that Lydia used to do that. But then Jenson started doing it aswell. To strangers and friends and things, it was just a normal kid chatting away to anybody. Ive always felt Ive got a little somebody following me around andits true then it is lovely. It brings some comfort to know that the baby is still there with us. If its not true, it doesnt matter as Ill never know either way anyway. Its just nice to think that.

title: mum who children dangle heads
story: NewsMum who let children dangle heads out of window of slow moving car for bit of fun is banned from drivingFormer probation officer Stefanie Oakley was stopped after passersby saw the children perched on the back window sillsShareByHayley Sewell:,  OCT NewsStefanie Oakley allowed her kids to dangle out the windows of her car "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who allowed her two children to dangle headfirst out of the back windows of her car for a bit of fun has been banned from driving. Stefanie Oakley, a former probation officer, was stopped by police after passersby spotted the children perched on the back window sills of her Skoda Octavia. Neither of them were wearing seat belts, and were hanging on to the roof rack while hanging out of the car. Oakley, , who home schools her children told officers she was only driving slowly and also suggested the incident would not be concerningit was another era. She and admitted previously letting the children hang out of the windows whilst their legs were inside the vehicle during a camping holiday. But Oakley, who regularly organises art and craft groups for children in the rural town of Chapel-Le-Frith, Derbyshire, was charged with dangerous driving - an offence which has a maximum sentence of two years in jail. Prosecutors said the children could have fallen out of the car into the path of oncoming traffic or under the wheels of her own car simplythe Skoda had hit a pothole.  The youngsters, aged six and seven - thought to be a boy and a girl - were unharmed in the incident. At Stockport Magistrates Court Oakley, who lives in the village of Hathersage, Derbyshire, admitted dangerous driving and driving while her children were not wearing seatbelts - but was given a  weeks jail suspended for a year. The incident occurred at .pm on July  after Oakley decided to take her children to the Kouros Meditterean cafe. Prosecuting Sonia Alford, said: This defendant was seen by police and civilians on, not one, but two occasions, driving through Chapel-en-le-Frith in Derbyshire. Firstly, she was seen at .pm by a civilian who saw two children with their bodies out of the vehicle and they were hanging onto a bar on the roof. They were six and seven. She made her way to a restaurant, Kouros Cafe then as she exited the restaurant, later, she was seen by staff and diners in the restaurant with her children sitting on the window sill of her car. As she pulls away, she is seen by a police officer and he shouts for her to stop. The police officer gets in his car and signals her to stop. He witnesses her drive about  metres. He asked what she was doing and she replied it was only a bit of fun. She continued to say this in her police interview.  The children are young enough to have car seats and they had them in the car. She said that previously she allowed them to do this on a campsite. She initially said it wasnt dangerous because she was driving slowly due to sheep being on the road. Though there were two incidents, I dont knowthe first one was prolonged. Its clear that there is not just a small risk of injury. If she had hit a pot hole, the children could have fallen out of her car and be hit by another car. A probation report about Oakley was read to the court, which said: At the time she hadnt considered how serious they wear or what harm couldve been caused to her children. She didnt envisage the matter being followed through. She had previously let the children sit on the windowsill and hang out of the window on campsites. Since being on holiday they have pestered her to allow them to do it again. Her thinking at the time was that it would be okay and didnt consider any of the consequences. The potential harm to the children was great. If they had slipped she couldve run over her own children oranother car had clipped them the same could have happened. She hadnt thought of other vehicles or the risks. She felt extremely embarrassed about herself. Her children her partner and herself have previously lived abroad in India for a year. This may have had an influence to her thoughts as they didnt have seatbelts there. It is not acceptable to put her children in that situation however. I do not think there was any intention to cause harm. Her parenting style has not caused any issues before. She lives with her partner and two children in a rented property and has lived there for just under three years.  She works one day a week at a restaurant as a waitress. Her partner works Monday Tuesday Wednesday and Friday in a local school dealing with morning and after school clubs. The children are homeschooled. She has previously been a probation officer, not since  and has a strong support network of friends and her partner, and she has a good character. Her lawyer Andrew Stewart said: This is a case of bad judgement on the defendants part. She travelled a short distance on two occasions in a rural area very slowly. On the second occasion, a police officer said he saw her drive about  metres from the restaurant. As soon as she is told that this is unacceptable, she stops the act. What she insists is that she was replicating behaviour from abroad. The children would hold onto the bars on the top of her car while she drives slowly. In another era, this might not have been as concerning as it is now. She thought about what she was allowed to do when she was little, and that she was stupid and didnt think of the risks. She worked as a probation officer for six years and she also worked as a young persons drug counsellor. She also volunteers for a local elderly charity. She is somebody who took time out of her career to home school her children. She is a caring mother and a valued member of the community, who organises outdoor and crafts groups for children. She is somebody who has never been in trouble before in her le. Oakley who was also ordered to complete  hours unpaid work told the court: I agree with everything that was said, but I dont feel like this was a bit of fun. I think it is really awful what I did. I just wanted to say I am sorry and it was really stupid. I feel terrible about putting my children in danger.I am an intelligent person but I just didnt think about the consequences.JP Lynn Bennison told her: Members of the public were so concerned that they contacted the police. Dangerous driving is so serious and the driving you demonstrated that day seriously endangered your children. Oakley was also ordered to pay pound in costs and surcharges.

title: queen kate middleton wore tiaras
story: NewsWhy the Queen and Kate Middleton wore tiaras to state dinners but Meghan Markle didntThis is what determines whether royal women wear tiaras at formal events or notShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  OCT News "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailState dinners are some of the rare occasions when royal women are allowed to wear fancy tiaras from the royal family’s collection. Given that the Queen wore one at the Fijian state banquet on her tour their in , royal fans speculated that this would be wear Meghan Markle made her tiara-debut. However, Meghan went for a more low-key look and did not wear any jewels on her head at the event. She looked stunning in a floor- blue gown and topped off her look with a dazzling pair of earrings.  Meanwhile, Kate Middleton wore a tiara last night at the Dutch state banquet. It was a beautul diamond-encrusted tiara Kate has worn several times before, the Cambridge Lovers Knot tiara, which once belonged to Princess Diana. So, why did the Queen and Kate wear tiaras at state dinners but Meghan didnt  It turns out that royal protocol regarding tiaras actually has nothing to do with the Duchesses royal ranks - so its not because Kate is closer to the crown.  The choice of whether or not to wear a tiara is determined by the dress code of the event, as well as personal preference. In this case, the event was evidently black tie - so a tiara is not necessary. Another important factor is that state dinners are less formal than state banquets, which could have been one of Meghans reasons for going tiara-free. She may also have been advised not to travel with the expensive jewellery.A royal source told Hello magazine that there was no expectation for the Duchess to wear a tiara at the event, but said she was suitably attired for a state occasion.

title: woman who falsely claimed pregnant
story: NewsWoman who ly claimed she was pregnant three times killed herself after becoming depressed she had no kidsDaria Blazejak, , ly claimed she was pregnant on three occasions, and told her family she felt "alone" before being found dead by her lodger in Middleton, Greater ManchesterShareCommentsByJonathan PicklesAbigail OLeary:,  OCT NewsDaria Blazejak, who suffered from depression and anxiety, longed for children "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman took a fatal overdose after becoming depressed due to her not having children, an inquest heard. Daria Blazejak, , ly claimed she was pregnant on three occasions, and told her family she felt alone. In April of this year, she also texted her boyfriend saying she was bad before being found dead at her home by her lodger in Middleton, Greater Manchester. Tests showed she had taken an overdose. The tragedy occurred a month after Polish-born Miss Blazejak, a warehouse data management operative, had been admitted to hospital following a previous overdose. Speaking at the Heywood hearing through a Polish interpreter, Miss Blazejaks sister, Marietta Zajac, said: Daria and I would speak from time to time, sometimes more than others. She had anxiety as well as severe back pain.  Sometimes she felt bad and sometimes she felt good, but many times she said that she wanted to die. About half a year before she died, her flatmate called me to tell me she had collapsed, and she needed to go to hospital. In January she rang me crying saying that she felt alone, that she didnt have any children and she didnt want to live anymore. In March, she rang my mum telling her that she wanted to hang herself. But afterwards, she didnt want to talk about it anymore. She would usually ring me after she had drunk alcohol. On two occasions, she rang me to tell me that she was pregnant, but she wasnt really. Miss Blazejaks ex-partner, Dominic Bradley, said: We first met about  years ago at work as friends. We worked at a storage warehouse and she was data management operative.  We started a relationship in January this year and there were a lot of highs and lows. I knew she was taking quite strong painkillers and on March  this year, she contacted me in the morning at am. I askedshe was OK and she said no and that she was a bad person and that she wanted to die. I asked hershe had taken something and she said yes, so I picked her up and took her to A+E. She had a mental health assessment at the hospital, but she said she didnt want to have one. She left hospital without taking the assessment. I found out and went around to her flat. I tried to encourage her to go back to hospital, but she refused. We had a disagreement after that and she blocked my number. On April , she told me that she wanted to move to London and I wished her good luck. On the following Saturday morning, at am, she rang me crying. She said she wanted me to pick her up from London. So, I went down later in the day and drove her back home. On April , she sent me a text message saying she was pregnant and she lost the baby and that it was my fault. I asked her to talk about it with me, but we didnt. I dont knowshe was pregnant or not. On Friday April , I messaged her, and she said she was bad. Then, on the Sunday I text her and I got nothing back.  In a statement, Miss Blazejaks GP, Dr Ritwik Raychaudhuri said: Daria was diagnosed with depression in  and was on medication in relation to that. Det Con Linda Senior said: There were no suspicious circumstances and no third-party involvement. I did some background checks and there was a lot of history between her and previous partners of turbulent relationships. But there was nothing suggesting any problems with Dominic. Recording a narrative conclusion, coroner Peter Sigee said: There was an incident where she appeared to take too much of her medication and her partner took her to the hospital where she had treatment. But she didnt say that she took that medication with the intention of taking her own le. Therefore I am satisfied that she did not intend to take her own le.If you are affected by any issues raised in this story, contact The Samaritans for confidential support on  .

title: heavily pregnant womans nightmare night
story: NewsHeavily pregnant womans nightmare night as husband suffers heart attack hours before shes due to give birthA couple were preparing to go to the hospital for the birth of their first child when the unthinkable happenedShareByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  OCT NewsAshley and Andrew were preparing for the birth of their first child when the unthinkable happened "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The birth of a child should be one of the happiest occasions of a persons le.But for two new parents from Saint Paul in Minnesota the day their child was born will be remembered for a rather dark reason.Ashley and Andrew Goette were preparing to go to the hospital so Ashleys labour could be induced.However just hours before they were due to leave for their appointment, the unthinkable happened and the mum-to-be awoke to find her husband suffering a heart attack.  While attempting not to panic for the sake of the baby, Ashley called emergency services who helped her perform CPR while they waited for an ambulance to arrive.However by the time paramedics reached Andrew, he was in full cardiac arrest and had been without oxygen for a y period, reports news.au.The ambulance team restarted the mans heart before taking him to hospital where he was placed in a medically induced coma in the intensive care unit. Ashley and other members of his family were told to prepare for the worst.  Doctors advised them that evenAndrew did come out of the coma, it was likely he would have a catastrophic brain injury. Not willing to leave her husbands side, Ashley decided to forgo her birth plans.I didnt want to have to think for one second about having to do any of this without him, she told Fox. I kept telling him the whole time he was asleep, or in his coma, that I was not going to have this baby until he woke up. And amazingly, thats just what happened. Andrew emerged from his coma, completely unscathed from any kind of brain damage and the following day his hospital bed was wheeled out of the ICU and parked beside his we while her labour was induced. But the complications didnt end there for the family. After several attempts to induce labour failed, doctors were forced to perform an emergency cesarean on Ashley.

title: town celebrates christmas two months
story: NewsTown celebrates Christmas two months early for poignant reasonNeighbours rallied together with a procession and festive decorations to make sure a -year-old boy had a special dayShareCommentsByChristopher Bucktin:,  OCT NewsPeople in the town of Stow, Ohio, US celebrating Christmas early "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email An entire town celebrated Christmas two months early to honour a terminally ill -year-old who may not live to see the big day.Keith Burkett has a rare form of childhood cancer in his skull, shoulder, spine and liver which doctors fear will claim his le before the end of the year. So the people of Stow, Ohio, rallied together to give him a Christmas he will never forget by decorating their homes, singing carols and dressing up as Santa. The special day included a ride in a fire engine, a procession of more than  cars festively decorated and even a medal for bravery from the towns mayor. Keith said: It was awesome. The fire truck was my favourite part because Ive never been in one before. I got to beep the horn.  His mum Taylore Woodard, a hair stylist, said: Doctors had told me that they didnt knowKeith would make it to Christmas. He loves Christmas. His le has been taken up with cancer and medicines and I wanted my son to enjoy one last Christmas. So at the end of September, we made our house into a winter wonderland. We put lights up, candy canes, polar bears and Santas. We had a North Pole sign and put up a banner that said, Merry Christmas Kourageous Keith.  Neighbours soon caught the Christmas spirit and began hanging their own decorations. She said: We noticed our next door neighbours put up some icicle lights and garlands and soon everyone was doing it. Brandy Spreizer, who runs a local lemonade stand, arranged for more than  drivers to decorate their cars in honour of poorly Keith on Sunday.  Hundreds of people then gathered at Stow-Munroe Falls High School as Christmas music played and the crowds waited for Keith to arrive. He was greeted at his home by friends dressed as Santa and elves from the North Pole. He rode in a fire truck to the high school where he saw all the vehicles decorated in his honour. Stow Councilman John Pribonic read a proclamation in Keiths honour and declared that October  was Keith Burkett Day. He was also given a medal from the mayor. Despite continual visits to hospital , it wasnt until March  that Keith was diagnosed with undferentiated soft tissue sarcoma and doctors removed cancer-ridden parts of his body in gruelling surgery.He also went through four courses of radiation and chemo but the cancer ed each time. In May this year, doctors found it had spread to the skull, left shoulder, lower part of his spine, his pelvis and his liver. Taylore, who is also mum to Adriana, seven, and Jax, six, said: Doctors told me that he wouldnt make it past Christmas.

story: NewsMums shocked after etiquette expert says children over five should give up seat on public transportAn etiquette expert has sparked a heated debate after sharing his thoughts on children using public transportShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  OCT NewsEtiquette expert claims young children should give up their seat on public transport "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Its half term, which means parents up and down the country are currently coming up with creative ways to entertain their little ones. title: besty lounge at dundee pub pays tribute to inspirational tracey
story: A lounge in a Dundee pub has been named after an “inspirational” woman who lost her battle with cancer last month.Tracey Burke, from Ardler, died on September , having fought the disease for three years.Tracey, , was planning her wedding day with husband Greg, , when she was given the devastating news she had cervical cancer.After a long period of gruelling treatment, she died surrounded by her family in the Roxburghe House hospice, her battle with the illness having touched people across Tayside.In just six weeks, the public raised a staggering £, to send her to Germany for immunotherapy, a pioneering treatment to try to cure her.The hashtag #teambesty was used on social media by supporters raising cash to highlight Tracey’s cause.Now, the Stobswell Bar on Dura Street has opened The Besty Lounge in Tracey’s honour.Greg said: “The Stobswell is our local – we were always in there. They’ve put the big sign up, but there’s also a collage of photos of Tracey in the corner, which is lovely.“It’s not a temporary thing either – it’s going to permanently be the Besty Lounge.“It’s a great tribute to Tracey and it was quite emotional seeing all the pictures. It was amazing to see just how loved she was and what high regard she was held in.”Greg is in the process of setting up a charity using the “besty” name to help local people with health problems. He will be a trustee along with Tracey’s mum, Pat, and other family members and friends.With some funds still in the coffers from the fundraising, Greg and the other trustees are looking to donate money to Perth youngster Lily Douglas.The -year-old was due to start cancer treatment in Spain on Monday. She was diagnosed with an aggressive form of lung cancer last month.She received the devastating news after being given the all-clear from stage four Ewing’s sarcoma, a rare form of bone cancer, having endured  rounds of chemotherapy.Mum Jane has now taken Lily to Spain where she will receive an alternative treatment to chemotherapy.Greg added: “Sending her abroad for pioneering treatment, which is what we did for Tracey, made it feel close to home.“I know what they are going through.“To be able to help them would make me feel so much better.”

title: george cran roles reversed as pressure now on dunfermline and allan johnston as dundee united look to gather momentum
story: With the first quarter of the season behind them, it’s fair to say it’s been a bumpy ride so far for Dundee United.Often coaches will use this point of the campaign as the first real chance to assess how things are going as they prepare to meet sides for the second time in the league.For the Tangerines, though, a report card right now can’t possibly tell the whole story with Csaba Laszlo not even lasting to this marker in charge of the team.And to judge his replacement Robbie Neilson after just two matches in charge wouldn’t be fair.However, comparing the fortunes of their next opponents Dunfermline since they met on the opening league match of the season makes for interesting reading.That’s because the atmosphere around Allan Johnston’s Pars since they finally overturned a -match winless run against the Tangerines to continue a lightning-fast start to the campaign has flipped almost completely.While the Tangerines struggled and stumbled under Csaba’s reign at the start of the season, Johnston was enjoying seeing his side inflict a - win at Tannadice to make it five wins from five games played after a % record in their Betfred Cup group.That was with an impressive  goals scored and included a deserved - win at Premiership Dundee.Now, though, Johnston faces a new man in the other dugout with intense scrutiny from fans now on him rather than his opposite number.After their perfect start to the campaign, it took Dunfermline another five matches to register a second victory in the Championship and have only racked up eight points from eight matches since.In the process they only managed six goals, conceding  and being dumped out of both the League Cup and Irn-Bru Cup on penalty shoot-outs.Going into Saturday’s game at East End Park, the Pars sit adrt of the play-off places, four points behind United in fourth place.Another poor result, after their - home defeat to Queen of the South at the weekend, will leave them well behind in the race for the top four, heaping all the pressure on Johnston and his side.And the contrast with Neilson, his United players and the atmosphere among the support is stark.After kicking off his reign with a - victory at Partick Thistle, the new gaffer led the Tangerines out for the first time at Tannadice at the weekend.Despite not managing to make it two wins from two, drawing - with Inverness CT, the players were boosted by the biggest home crowd of the campaign.The belief that Neilson can repeat the feat of promotion to the Premiership he achieved at Hearts is clear among the United support.Optimism throughout the stands has been almost completely absent over the past couple of seasons but the hope is now with former chairman Stephen Thompson having departed, and Neilson taking the reigns, good times might be on the horizon.And the ideal time to fuel that fire is now with games against sides below them in the table coming up – Dunfermline this weekend and then Queens the week after.With both the sides coming up in indferent form, points are a must to keep the good feeling flowing.Because what Dunfermline did show the last time the teams met, despite what’s happened since, is they can actually beat their bogey side United.What Neilson can’t afford now is to let the early momentum slip away, something that happened with both Ray McKinnon and, more obviously, Csaba Laszlo.Preventing that could well show the fans’ early optimism is justied come the season end.
